channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: 3 Rights Advocates Are Sentenced to Prison in China
item.description: The advocates were sentenced to terms ranging from two and a half to five years after they were convicted of inciting subversion in the southern city of Guangzhou.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, Pakistani Diplomat, Dies at 95
item.description: Mr. Yaqub Khan had a role in facilitating President Richard Nixon’s overture to China in 1972 and helped negotiate the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, center, at a reception in Washington in 1977, when he was Pakistan’s ambassador to the United States. With him are the Egyptian ambassador at the time, Ashraf Ghorbal, left, and the Iranian ambassador, Ardeshir Zahedi. The event recognized the three men’s effort in ending the so-called Hanafi siege.

item.title: World Briefing: Gaza: 7 Members of Hamas Killed in Tunnel Collapse
item.description: The members of Hamas’s military wing were repairing a tunnel into Israel that was used for several attacks against Israeli forces during the 2014 war.
item.dc:creator: MAJD AL WAHEIDI

item.title: More Is Needed to Beat ISIS, U.S. Military Concludes
item.description: To deal a lasting blow to the extremist Sunni militancy, officials believe that additional forces will be needed to work with Iraqi, Kurdish and Syrian opposition fighters.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: United States-led coalition instructors trained Iraqi Army soldiers in a joint live-ammunition exercise on Wednesday at a military base south of Baghdad.

item.title: Plotters Talked of Planting Explosives on a Kangaroo in Australia
item.description: A teenager, who pleaded not guilty to terrorism charges on Thursday, is accused of planning a holiday attack on the police in a Melbourne suburb.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Syrian Opposition Bloc Still Won’t Commit to Joining Peace Talks
item.description: A spokesman for the main opposition bloc said it wanted an assurance from Secretary General Ban Ki-moon that the Syrian government would lift its sieges of rebel-held towns.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The aftermath of an airstrike in the rebel-held area of Douma, on the outskirts of Damascus, on Wednesday.

item.title: New Details of Iran Ordeal Emerge From Former Prisoners
item.description: Jason Rezaian of The Washington Post and Matthew Trevithick added to the picture that has been emerging about the prisoner ordeal and the diplomacy that led to their release.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: China to Try Canadian on Spying Charges
item.description: Kevin Garratt, who ran a cafe near China’s border with North Korea, will be tried on charges of spying and stealing state secrets nearly a year and a half after he and his wife were detained.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Editorial: Moderates Under Pressure in Iran
item.description: Next month’s elections do not bode well for Iranians eager for more political and social freedoms.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Russia Dismisses German Claims of Exploiting Teen Rape Case
item.description: Russia’s foreign minister said a girl’s disappearance and alleged rape in Berlin was “hushed up.” But German officials have warned against politicizing the case.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO and ALISON SMALE

item.title: Pardon Plea by Adolf Eichmann, Nazi War Criminal, Is Made Public
item.description: Israel released the handwritten letter by Mr. Eichmann in which he denies guilt, saying Nazi officials like him were “mere instruments in the hands of leaders.”
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Adolf Eichmann’s handwritten letter in German from 1962 requesting a pardon was made public on Wednesday in Jerusalem by the Israeli president’s office.

item.title: Matteo Renzi, Italian Premier, Pushes for a Place at Europe’s Power Table
item.description: With the European Union fragmenting politically and hit by crises, Mr. Renzi is demanding that Italy’s voice be heard. But his assertiveness comes with political risk.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi speaking in the Senate in Rome. “I’m the leader of a great country,” Mr. Renzi said in a recent interview. “I have my ideas.”

item.title: Signs of Modern Astronomy Seen in Ancient Babylon
item.description: Scientists have found a small clay tablet with markings indicating that a sort of precalculus technique was used to track Jupiter’s motion in the night sky.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG
item.media:credit: Left to right: Trustees of the British Museum/Mathieu Ossendrijver; NASA
item.media:description: Clay tablets, including one at the left, revealed that Babylonian astronomers employed a sort of precalculus to describe Jupiter’s motion across the night sky relative to distant background stars. They did this 15 centuries earlier than Europeans were first credited with making such measurements.

item.title: Pakistan School Closings Stir Confusion, and Fears of More Attacks
item.description: The closing of the Pakistani military’s network of colleges and schools around Karachi in the wake of the Taliban attack at Bacha Khan University prompted worry among parents.
item.category: Army Public School and Degree College (Peshawar, Pakistan)
item.dc:creator: SABA IMTIAZ
item.media:description: A member of Pakistan’s Elite Police Force took part in a security drill at a school in Peshawar on Thursday.

item.title: Researchers Weigh Risks of Zika Spreading at Rio Olympics
item.description: Of the visitors expected to pour into Brazil in August, some may get infected by the mosquito-borne virus and then return home at a time of peak mosquito activity.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and REBECCA R. RUIZ

item.title: Bomb Kills 8 in Yemen Near President’s Residence
item.description: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi was unhurt in the blast, which hit a checkpoint nearby. But it underscored the government’s tenuous hold on security.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI

item.title: 7 Hamas Members Are Killed in Tunnel Collapse in Gaza
item.description: The men were repairing an old cross-border tunnel in eastern Gaza used in the war last year when it collapsed, Hamas said. Four workers survived.
item.dc:creator: MAJD AL WAHEIDI

item.title: Zika Virus ‘Spreading Explosively’ in Americas, W.H.O. Says
item.description: Officials from the group announced that they would convene a meeting on Monday to decide whether to declare a public health emergency.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: A Health Ministry employee fumigated a home to combat the Zika virus in Soyapango, El Salvador, on Wednesday.

item.title: Taxing Google and Other U.S. Giants Is Dividing Europe
item.description: European Union officials in Brussels want uniform rules, but many countries prefer to use tax policies to reward or punish big multinationals.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: The European Union’s competition commissioner, Margrethe Vestager, second from left, spoke with the E.U.’s commissioner for economic and financial affairs, Pierre Moscovici, during a meeting in Brussels on Wednesday.

item.title: Armed Man Arrested at Disneyland Paris
item.description: A 28-year-old man carrying two guns, ammunition and a Quran was arrested at a hotel in Disneyland Paris, adding to security fears in France.
item.dc:creator: DAPHNÉ ANGLÈS and HANNAH OLIVENNES
